title: How to Set Up Chain and Ring Topologies in Networking: Step-by-Step Guide
description:
In this video, we walk you through the process of setting up Chain and Ring topologies in a network environment. Learn the key differences between these two network topologies, including their benefits and drawbacks. We provide a step-by-step guide to configuring each topology, covering best practices for ensuring optimal network performance, reliability, and scalability. Whether you're designing a small office network or planning a large enterprise infrastructure, understanding how to set up Chain and Ring topologies is crucial for network architects and engineers.

title: What Is Stacking in Networking? Benefits and Configurations Explained
description:
In this video, we explain the concept of ""stacking"" in networking, a configuration method that allows multiple physical network switches to operate as a single logical unit. Learn how stacking improves scalability, simplifies management, and enhances redundancy. We will also cover the different types of stacking methods, including hardware and software-based solutions, and how they benefit modern network infrastructures. Discover how stacking increases network efficiency and performance, helping businesses meet their growing connectivity needs.
  
  Related links:
  Cisco Switch Stacking Overview → https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/smb/switches/cisco-350x-series-stackable-managed-switches/smb5252-what-is-stacking.html?dtid=osclytb001771
  Cisco Catalyst Switches → https://www.cisco.com/site/us/en/products/networking/switches/catalyst-9000-switches/index.html?dtid=osclytb001771
  
  What you’ll learn in this video:
  – The concept and benefits of network switch stacking
  – How stacking improves scalability and network performance
  – The differences between hardware and software-based stacking
  – Best practices for configuring stacked switches in a network
  
  This video is ideal for network engineers, IT professionals, and system administrators who want to understand how stacking works and how it can be implemented in their network infrastructure.

title: Cisco Tech Talk: Configuring Routing Information Protocol (RIP) on Cisco Small Business Switches
description: Learn how and why to configure Routing Information Protocol (RIP) on Small Business Switches. Routing Information Protocol (RIP) is an implementation of a distance-vector protocol for local and wide-area networks. It classifies routers as either active or passive (silent). Active routers advertise their routes to others; passive routers listen and update their routes based on advertisements, but do not advertise. Typically, routers run RIP in active mode, while hosts use passive mode. For additional support information, visit the Cisco Small Business Support Community: http://cs.co/9002DF7ts.

title: Cisco Tech Talk: What is Cisco Discovery Protocol (CDP)
description: The Cisco Discovery Protocol, or CDP, enables networking applications to learn about directly connecteddevices nearby. This protocol facilitates the management of Cisco devices by discovering these devices, determining how they are configured, and allowing systems using different network-layer protocols to learn about each other.Learn more about the Cisco Discovery Protocol here.

description: Session Initiation Protocol, or SIP, is a control protocol that can be used to establish, maintain, or terminate calls among two or more endpoints. Learn how to define a new SIP extension on this edition of Cisco Tech Talks.

title: Cisco Tech Talk: How to Update the Firmware of the Base Station

title: Cisco Tech Talk: Conquering CPU Utilization Troubleshooting on Cisco Small Business Switches
description:
Tackling high CPU utilization on your Cisco small business switches? In this Tech Talk, we’ll explore practical troubleshooting techniques to identify and resolve performance issues. Learn how Secure Core Technology (SCT) safeguards your device, how to monitor CPU usage through both the GUI and CLI, and how to optimize your network by managing MAC address tables, ARP entries, and access lists. Discover actionable tips to reduce CPU strain and ensure optimal device performance. Watch now to master the art of troubleshooting CPU utilization on Cisco switches!

In this Cisco Tech Talk, learn how to use VRRP (Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol) and VRID (Virtual Router Identifier) to enhance network management and failover capabilities. This video demonstrates how these protocols allow for seamless redundancy and failover between network routers, ensuring high availability and uninterrupted connectivity. Discover the benefits of using VRRP for load balancing and improving network resilience.

  What you’ll learn in this video:
  – How VRRP and VRID work together to enhance network redundancy and failover
  – The process of configuring VRRP on Cisco routers for optimal network performance
  – How to use VRID for improved network management and failover scenarios
  
  This video is perfect for network engineers and IT professionals looking to increase network reliability and ensure business continuity through VRRP and VRID.

In this Cisco Tech Talk, we show you how to flash firmware on Cisco CBS Series switches to resolve boot errors, corruption, or upgrade failures. This advanced procedure can restore stability and functionality when normal upgrades don't work.
 

Related link:
CBS Series Firmware Upgrade Guide → https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/smb/switches/Cisco-Business-Switching/kmgmt-2524-2545-upgrade-firmware-cbs.html?dtid=osclytb001771
 

What you’ll learn in this video:
 – When to flash firmware vs. standard upgrade
 – How to access recovery mode and reload firmware
 – Tips to validate the firmware restore and avoid repeat issues
 

 Flashing firmware can bring a failed switch back to life. This video gives you the safe, correct method to do it on Cisco CBS switches.

title: Cisco Tech Talk: How to Change Your DNS Settings with Google DNS, OpenDNS & Cloudflare - Part 2
description:
Welcome back to Cisco Tech Talk! In part two of our DNS series, learn how to change DNS settings on your entire network. Switching to a public DNS like Google DNS ensures every device—PCs, smartphones, printers, smart home gadgets—enjoys faster speeds, better uptime, and enhanced security. 

Why Change DNS at the Router Level? 
Changing the DNS server at the router level means every device that connects to your Wi-Fi network will automatically use your chosen public DNS server, like Google DNS, OpenDNS, or Cloudflare DNS, without needing to configure each device individually. 

Missed part 1? Watch it here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Hqxy7nL3gGo]
